reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2009, traveled solo
reviews.text: Hiiragiya far exceeded my expectations at maintaining the cultural integrity of the past. I agree whole heartedly with the other reviewers' opinions of this ryokan sanctuary.
reviews.title: A True Japanese Sanctuary

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Originally a tea room (old section #36, no bath - bathroom was two doors down where I had the opportunity to experience their high-tech toilet with all those buttons and gizmos. I was glad to select the "mature" wing. My room was the smallest one on the property but I did not feel confined. The clean, simplistic lines was very calming after a hectic day of sightseeing. There was no distractions of the outside world here. The Japanese garden outside my sliding glass doors also added to the atmosphere. I guess it's all about personal preference on location of your room. I did see the new wing and even though they did a great job with blending both wings, it felt too new. This was a stretch for me in trying a ryokan experience and I am glad I took the risk. Slept like a baby here.
reviews.title: Quite an experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The other stretch for me was to experience a kaiseki meal as in the past I wasn't too fond of raw fish. I had heard earlier that Japanese food tastes rather bland but I wanted to make my own opinion. For the Japanese, it's not only the taste that is important, it's the food's consistency when felt inside the mouth, such as rice grains and slices of raw fish. That's where Hiiragiya comes in. Their aesthetic menu selection was tasty morsefuls from heaven. Of particular mention was one of their feature dishes (Hassun) - sushi of salmon roe, sea bream bound together with egg, grilled prawn with botargo, ginko nut and pumpkin. Their grilled butterfish marinated in saikyo miso was also a delight. I am glad I suspended my food judgment until I tried it all. "Go-chiso-sama" - what a feast.
reviews.title: Perfection found in Kyoto

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed June 2008, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Mrs. Akemi's commitment to preserving the traditional spirit and refined manners of the past is to be commended. I definitely felt the "ki" (energy) here. On a scale of 1-5, (five being excellent) both Asuka and Mrs. Reiko get a 6 (!) They were always available to assist in any way to make my stay memorable. Long live civility.
reviews.title: Completely fascinating...at a price

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2007, traveled with family
reviews.text: Expensive, but worth it. The rooms were immaculate. The service was perfect. Every little detail was accounted for.
reviews.title: Ryokan at it´s best

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed July 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Stayed here in July 2010, and have been meaning to write this review. Details still crisp.
reviews.title: Waste of Money, Could not wait to Check into airy Hyatt

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed February 2012, traveled solo
reviews.text: Travel Specialist pushed this for "unique Japanese" experience as part of trip through Japan, Singapore and Bali (see related reviews). May have been a great idea in theory, but was not great in practice. One night there was very very expensive and not worth it for me. And I typically love boutique properties. Some may find this old world charming, but in fact the "original"" building (that we checked out when we were there to see which we preferred as they had additional vacancy) was dilapidated and moldy, downright awful. Looked like the old camp bunks we may have walked out of as children! Even the new rooms, which were pretty and happy, was cramped space,with low-ceilings,and felt almost claustrophobic. Yes, the bath is lovely, but $1000 bucks for a soak? I think not.
reviews.title: Great service. Ryokan needs a litte refurbishment however.

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: The women who work there are very sweet, guests donning Japanese clothing and footwear is darling, but that is about it for the pluses. I thought the food was subpar; how disappointing...as I LOVE sushi, but the dinner consisted of weird tastes and textures. Additionally, upon checkin you had to inform reception the exact time you wanted breakfast in the morning---- how on earth do I know on a Friday vacation afternoon what time I will wake up and be hungry on a Saturday morning? Moreover, every time I asked for coffee or tea they charged significant room service fee. Oh, and compulsory shoe removal wears thin when it is raining and your tall husband has to keep bending in half to untie his shoelaces. .
reviews.title: Overpriced

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed November 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: By the time we checked out and moved to the Hyatt for the rest of our Kyoto stay, we felt like we had returned "home", a welcoming understanding environment that provided terrific service and good food at normal prices.
reviews.title: Hiiragiya - Wow

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed September 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: My recommendation? Visit a Ryokan for tea, sleep elsewhere!
reviews.title: Heavenly Service

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed December 2010, traveled with family
reviews.text: Wow, talk about a difference experience! This was our first time in a ryokan, and it was a very memorable stay. We knew we wanted to try one night, so we picked (based on our research) the best one there is. The Hiiragiya didn't disappoint. The service is so attentive and the sense of culture permeates everywhere. The staff are all in traditional wear and the room we had was decked out in traditional tatami mats, wooden baths, etc. Okay, you do have to have some conveniences, such as the typical Japanese spray toilet. They even drape a cover over the tv and phone so that its discreetly hidden within the beautifully decorated room. The highlight of course are the meals. I must say after the Kaiseki dinner, I would suggest this be on everyone's "to do in their lifetime" list. The meal was simply outstanding. Just when you think you had enough, you get another outstanding meal for breakfast. My wife and I had the Japanese breakfast and our two young daughters had the western breakfast. I would suggest the Japanese breakfast was better with more variety and interesting things. Given all this, your still sleeping on the floor in one big room. The staff do a great job setting up the sleeping gear, but it still is not as comfortable as a good bed. The pillows were just okay too. A stay at the Hiiragiya is extremely expensive, thus the one night stay. That may be enough after two outstanding meals. All in all, a must do and an experience of a lifetime.
reviews.title: A Must to Try at Least Once

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We spent one perfect evening in the original, old wing. Our rooms were spacious, beautiful, every detail thoughtfully and perfectly arranged. The in-room bath was terrific. Our kaiseki meal was beautifully prepared and served in our room. Our main server was fluent in English which was especially helpful. They carefully and gracefully accommodated everyone's various food issues and allergies. Our meals were works of art. Seasonal, local foods prepared in the traditional manner. First rate. Japanese breakfast was absolute perfection. If you visit Kyoto, this is an experience not to be missed, worth every penny. Sufficient modern amenities, too, for the fussy Western traveler. The neighborhood is terrific, well worth strolling around. Great shopping.
reviews.title: A Lovely Traditional Ryokan Experience Worth Every Penny

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We spent 3 nights here at the end of a wonderful tour of Japan and the Hiiragiya perfectly embodied the best of Japanese culture. From the wonderful food and attentive service down to the tiniest details like the wooden bucket used for bathing that was made by a "Living Treasure" everything was perfect. We stayed in the old part of the inn in a room where Mr. Kawabata stayed and that added to our enjoyment. The view of a small garden was delightful while sipping tea and enjoying sweets. The staff was wonderful, the owner was especially helpful with suggestions about what to see and do. The neighbourhood was interesting and close to many of the places we wanted to see.
reviews.title: Perfectly Japanese

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed January 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We spent 2 wonderful nights at Hiiragiya. Stayed there for our honeymoon in a room located at the new wing. The room was luxurious and beautiful. We have a little private garden in our room. Really love the wooden bath and the high tech toilet. The futon was really comfortable. The Kaiseki dinner was wonderful and delicious. The breakfast was also really delicious. We try both the Japanese breakfast and the western breakfast. The service was second to none. They prepare hot water in the wooden bath every day. The staffs were very friendly and helpful. Some of the staffs spoke good English, including our room maid Haruka. Haruka brings English newspaper every morning. The owner came to our room one night when we were having a kaiseki dinner. She apologizes to us because she can’t greet us when we arrived there. She bring a card (which she wrote personally) congratulate us for our honeymoon and gave us a pair of chopstick as a gift. The price was not cheap but worth every penny. Glad we chose Hirragiya for our honeymoon.
reviews.title: Luxurious Traditional Ryokan

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed October 2009, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: We spent two nights at Hiiragiya and really enjoyed it. We had a very nice room in the old part, with a view of the peaceful garden. The ryokan is close to perfect. The room was very nice, the service perfect, the attention to detail in the decor unbelievable, and the food delicious. I don't really know how best to describe it.
reviews.title: Fantastic experience

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed August 2010, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Staying here was the one of the best things that I've ever done. Food, service, atmosphere and over all experience was nothing short of perfection.
reviews.title: Don't die without experiencing this place

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed March 2011, traveled solo
reviews.text: This is the second time I stayed at the Hiiragiya, both as a solo traveler. I already booked another stay, this time with my family.
reviews.title: Exquisite, traditional Kyoto ryokan

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed May 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: I chose the original wing both times, and I think it is just amazing to be in a room which is so full of history, yet as comfortable as one can desire. Attention to detail and service standards are the highlights of this ryokan. I chose one of the larger rooms, which has a beautiful view of the Japanese garden, including a small stream with a few resident fish. It was very relaxing being in the seating area contemplating the view and enjoying tea and Japanese wagashi (typical sweets).
reviews.title: a taste of old world kyoto

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2011, traveled as a couple
reviews.text: Words cannot describe the quality of the food. Staying two nights, the ryokan was able to present me with two completely different Kaiseki meals for dinner, both of which showcased the seasonal ingredients from early spring.
reviews.title: Amazing

reviews.stay_parameters: Stayed April 2011, traveled with family
reviews.text: The Japanese breakfast is also quite impressive and adds to the experience of staying at a ryokan. Both times I stayed at Hiiragiya, I opted for the Japanese breakfast, so can't comment on the western option.
reviews.title: excellent stay
